docs.snippet: General Sergun managed Russia’s military intelligence service, known as the G.R.U., which has been accused of playing a crucial role in the 2014 takeover of Crimea....
docs.lead_paragraph: General Sergun managed Russia’s military intelligence service, known as the G.R.U., which has been accused of playing a crucial role in the 2014 takeover of Crimea.
docs.abstract: Col Gen Igor D Sergun, director of Main Intelligence Directorate of Russia’s General Staff, who played crucial role in 2014 takeover of Crimea, dies at age 58.

headline.main: Igor D. Sergun, Chief of Russian Military Intelligence, Dies at 58
headline.print_headline: Igor D. Sergun, 58, Military Intelligence Chief

docs.snippet: Russia is a mafia state, not only because it is run like the mafia but also because it is run by organized crime....
docs.lead_paragraph: Russia is a mafia state, not only because it is run like the mafia but also because it is run by organized crime.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Masha Gessen argues recent court proceedings in Britian and Spain, along with two films and several journalistic investigations, show Pres Vladimir V Putin runs Russia with apparent links to one of country's most well-known organized crime families.

docs.snippet: Finland staged a late comeback with three goals in the third period of a 4-3 win at the world junior hockey championship. The United States beat Sweden, 8-3, for the bronze....
docs.lead_paragraph: Finland staged a late comeback with three goals in the third period of a 4-3 win at the world junior hockey championship. The United States beat Sweden, 8-3, for the bronze.
docs.abstract: Finland beats Russia, 4-3, to win gold medal at world junior hockey championship in Helsinki.

headline.main: Finland Rallies Past Russia for Juniors Title
headline.print_headline: Finland Rallies Past Russia for Title

docs.snippet: The European Court of Human Rights ruled in favor of a Russian man who was detained during a political rally in 2012 and who was sentenced to two weeks in jail for jaywalking....
docs.lead_paragraph: The European Court of Human Rights ruled in favor of a Russian man who was detained during a political rally in 2012 and who was sentenced to two weeks in jail for jaywalking.
docs.abstract: European Court of Human Rights rules in favor of Russian protester Yevgeniy Frumkin, who was sentenced to two weeks in jail for jaywalking at political rally in Moscow in 2012, and orders Russian government to pay Frumkin more than $30,000 in damages and expenses; says there was no way Frumkin could comply with police officer's demands given tight confines and large crowd of people.

headline.main: European Court Orders Russia to Pay Damages to Protester
headline.print_headline: Russia Is Ordered to Pay Damages to a Protester

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
